The reason I missed 4/8 classes is because I withdrew from the class.

I wasn’t certain if "administratively dropped" meant “drop, as in weeks 1-3 drop where you become a part-time student, even at the end of the quarter” or “drop, as in whichever drop fits the current week, so a W or NP depending when it happens”. I didn’t have much confidence that I would be able to avoid missing 3 classes over a ten-week period, and didn’t want to risk being dropped in the first way and becoming a part-time student, so as soon as I was able to withdraw from CMPM 179 (thus keeping full-time student status in exchange for a W grade) I did so. I’m on track to graduate even with a dropped class this quarter and part-time status would mean losing some financial aid, so it was the safer option to withdraw manually. It was a calculated decision.

I really did enjoy the class while I was there, and I’m sure that would continue since I had a good experience taking ART 101 with you as the instructor, but the attendance policy made it feel too risky. I appreciate you writing to give me another chance, as well as a past email encouraging me to keep going. It really does mean a lot. But this whole problem started because I didn’t trust that I could maintain perfect attendance throughout the quarter, and even with a second chance, I don’t think that changes. So I’d rather take a W now than risk a NP later.

Best of luck with the rest of the quarter.

Hi Person P,

I understand. I got you. It never occurred to me that the policy might completely scare some students away. I will clarify it in the future. It is meant to be motivational not punitive. Thank you for the feedback. I'm sure it will help.

I would love to take your class and learn the basics of coding and how to apply it to the arts. At this point we are entering week 4 of a 10 week course. Meaning you have missed 40% of the course so far. That means you’ve missed nine hours of lecture, 12 hours of section, three labs and three other assignments. You’ve missed numerous opportunities to collaborate with other students. Project group assignments have already been made. If you had asked to join during week 1 or week 2, We could’ve worked something out. But at this point I’m sorry to say I’m afraid it’s just too late in the class for you to be successful. I hope you will take the class next time it is offered. Good luck finding a class.

I was a student in your ART 101 class last Fall quarter and received an A. For this quarter, I am currently taking your CMPM 179 and I’m grateful to learn from you once again.

As I had planned, I’m preparing to apply to graduate schools and would like to know if you would be comfortable writing a letter of recommendation on my behalf. I’d appreciate it if you could consider my request. Thank you for your time.

I'd be happy to consider writing you a recommendation letter. In order to make a decision about whether I can help you, a little more info might help. (And as you are writing to other recommenders, here's the starting point you'd normally send to a recommender with your request for a letter.)

- What's your relationship with the prof, for example, what class and quarter did you have together, what grade did you get, and what memorable projects were you part of?
- What school/program/employer are you applying to?
- What is the deadline for the recommendation? (my advice is to always subtract a week to prevent faculty being late)

If your recommender says yes, then they'll need a bit more info:

- Your CV or resume
- A portfolio including Screenshots, descriptions , or links to relevant work
- Other relevant work. If in doubt, don't include it.
- A link to the position to which you are applying

I always like to offer to draft a recommendation letter highlighting things I consider important for the position. This is helpful to some profs, and serves as a jumping off point. When I ask for recommendations, I have a draft letter as a google doc I send as a link.

Hope this helps.

Can I get an an add code to enroll in your class?

Here is a secret that no one ever tells you about undergraduate education: even if a class is full, if you attend the class and the sections you want, because of inevitable attrition, a space will eventually open up. I’ll add you to the online course as soon as I set it up. I can also give you a permission code the first or second week (since I won't have them until then). You will then still have to settle up with the registrar to become officially registered. See you in class.
